posts.name: owen
posts.cooked: I was recently looking into the smallest FRC legal robots and that got me thinking What was the biggest? I instantly thought Rycycle rush because of the nearly limitless robot restrictions. But when I looked it up I couldn‚Äôt find anything. And when I checked Chief Delphi I also found nothing useful, so now I am asking ‚ÄúWhat was the Bigest FRC robot ever?‚Äù

link_counts.title: What's some of the smallest (frame perimeter/height/volume) and largest robots ever built?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
The FlopBots.

These robots had a drivetrain that sat vertically in the starting configuration, then they fell down after match start. There are quite a few, many notable in their own right.

71, 2002: Probably the largest wingspan, and also could reach back to its home zone if I remember right. 67, 2005, and 340, 2005: These two had tall reach to go with their large drivebase, but didn‚Äôt have a lot of wingspan. 16, 2008: Not the largest‚Ä¶ but when you have a (comparatively) half-width field, it had a pretty decent percentage of field occupied.

Also, look before 2006, because there weren‚Äôt as many expansion restrictions then.

posts.name: Matt Golman
posts.cooked: 2015 is going to be a weird outlier because there were team like 148 that did field-spanning multibots. Other than that, I‚Äôd probably give it to one of the old school flop bots like 67 in 2005.

link_counts.title: History Lesson | Four Famous ‚ÄúFlops‚Äù ‚Äì The Blue Alliance Blog

posts.name: owen
posts.cooked: What was the point of the flop bots?

posts.name: Cory Walters
posts.cooked: 2007 giant ramp bots. I would rule out all tether machines

posts.name: CoreyBrown
posts.cooked:
Old school flip bots are definitely the place to look.

The more modern era of FRC has had a few large robots outside of 2015 as well:

1710 in 2014 - about 80 inches wide, and 96 inches tall.

190 in 2008 (is 2008 the modern era still or am I old now?) - looks about 8 feet tall, and could flail out pretty far as it swung the giant game piece around the field.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: More area down low. Bigger robots while still staying in the size limits.

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked:
Adding onto this - the OG 68 bot in 03 spanned the field.

But yeah, having been around a lot of these bots up close - 16 in 08 just feels massive. I think 2014 made us all forget how giant a horse soccer ball is.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Andrew_Schreiber:

a horse soccer ball

huh

TIL

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
The ramp barricade robots from 2003 were pretty impressive. (I am still not convinced that 68 deserved the late-breaking ruling that it was illegal to use when extending loosely over both sides of the middle rail.)

FIRST Robotics Competition team from Ortonville, Michigan, USA.
